Key Arguments: The bill is based on an unfounded assertion that misinformation and disinformation pose a significant threat.
Increased censorship and monitoring are unnecessary as Australians have largely complied with government directives in the past.
Dissenting opinions are essential for societal advancement and trust-building.
The bill risks stifling necessary debate and could lead to authoritarian control over information.
Historical examples show that accepted truths can later be proven wrong, highlighting the need for open discussion.
The bill is patronizing and assumes Australians cannot make informed decisions.
The role of government should not be to control information for safety.
Notable Quotes: Dissenting opinions are required in order to advance society and build trust.
This bill feels very patronising. It seems to assume that Australians are really stupid and can’t make informed decisions.
Ingenuity is fostered through rigorous debate and sharing all sorts of ideas, please don’t hamstring our great country.
